packageMeta.name: purescript-filterable
packageMeta.description: Classes for filterable and witherable data structures

declarations.comments:
`Compactable` represents data structures which can be _compacted_/_filtered_.
This is a generalization of catMaybes as a new function `compact`. `compact`
has relations with `Functor`, `Applicative`, `Monad`, `Plus`, and `Traversable`
in that we can use these classes to provide the ability to operate on a data type
by eliminating intermediate Nothings. This is useful for representing the
filtering out of values, or failure.

To be compactable alone, no laws must be satisfied other than the type signature.

If the data type is also a Functor the following should hold:

- Functor Identity: `compact <<< map Just ≡ id`

According to Kmett, (Compactable f, Functor f) is a functor from the
kleisli category of Maybe to the category of Hask.
`Kleisli Maybe -> Hask`.

If the data type is also `Applicative` the following should hold:

- `compact <<< (pure Just <*> _) ≡ id`
- `applyMaybe (pure Just) ≡ id`
- `compact ≡ applyMaybe (pure id)`

If the data type is also a `Monad` the following should hold:

- `flip bindMaybe (pure <<< Just) ≡ id`
- `compact <<< (pure <<< (Just (=<<))) ≡ id`
- `compact ≡ flip bindMaybe pure`

If the data type is also `Plus` the following should hold:

- `compact empty ≡ empty`
- `compact (const Nothing <$> xs) ≡ empty`
declarations.title: Compactable

declarations.comments:
`Compactable` represents data structures which can be _compacted_/_filtered_.
This is a generalization of catMaybes as a new function `compact`. `compact`
has relations with `Functor`, `Applicative`, `Monad`, `Plus`, and `Traversable`
in that we can use these classes to provide the ability to operate on a data type
by eliminating intermediate Nothings. This is useful for representing the
filtering out of values, or failure.

To be compactable alone, no laws must be satisfied other than the type signature.

If the data type is also a Functor the following should hold:

- Functor Identity: `compact <<< map Just ≡ id`

According to Kmett, (Compactable f, Functor f) is a functor from the
kleisli category of Maybe to the category of Hask.
`Kleisli Maybe -> Hask`.

If the data type is also `Applicative` the following should hold:

- `compact <<< (pure Just <*> _) ≡ id`
- `applyMaybe (pure Just) ≡ id`
- `compact ≡ applyMaybe (pure id)`

If the data type is also a `Monad` the following should hold:

- `flip bindMaybe (pure <<< Just) ≡ id`
- `compact <<< (pure <<< (Just (=<<))) ≡ id`
- `compact ≡ flip bindMaybe pure`

If the data type is also `Plus` the following should hold:

- `compact empty ≡ empty`
- `compact (const Nothing <$> xs) ≡ empty`
declarations.title: Compactable

declarations.comments:
`Filterable` represents data structures which can be _partitioned_/_filtered_.

- `partitionMap` - partition a data structure based on an either predicate.
- `partition` - partition a data structure based on boolean predicate.
- `filterMap` - map over a data structure and filter based on a maybe.
- `filter` - filter a data structure based on a boolean.

Laws:
- Functor Relation: `filterMap identity ≡ compact`
- Functor Identity: `filterMap Just ≡ identity`
- Kleisli Composition: `filterMap (l <=< r) ≡ filterMap l <<< filterMap r`

- `filter ≡ filterMap <<< maybeBool`
- `filterMap p ≡ filter (isJust <<< p)`

- Functor Relation: `partitionMap identity ≡ separate`
- Functor Identity 1: `_.right <<< partitionMap Right ≡ identity`
- Functor Identity 2: `_.left <<< partitionMap Left ≡ identity`

- `f <<< partition ≡ partitionMap <<< eitherBool` where `f = \{ no, yes } -> { left: no, right: yes }`
- `f <<< partitionMap p ≡ partition (isRight <<< p)` where `f = \{ left, right } -> { no: left, yes: right}`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `partitionDefault`
- `partitionDefaultFilter`
- `partitionDefaultFilterMap`
- `partitionMapDefault`
- `filterDefault`
- `filterDefaultPartition`
- `filterDefaultPartitionMap`
- `filterMapDefault`
declarations.title: Filterable

declarations.comments: Upgrade a boolean-style predicate to an either-style predicate mapping.
declarations.title: eitherBool

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `partition` using `partitionMap`.
declarations.title: partitionDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `partition` using `filter`. Note that this is
almost certainly going to be suboptimal compared to direct implementations.
declarations.title: partitionDefaultFilter

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `partition` using `filterMap`. Note that this
is almost certainly going to be suboptimal compared to direct
implementations.
declarations.title: partitionDefaultFilterMap

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `partitionMap` using `separate`. Note that this is
almost certainly going to be suboptimal compared to direct implementations.
declarations.title: partitionMapDefault

declarations.comments: Upgrade a boolean-style predicate to a maybe-style predicate mapping.
declarations.title: maybeBool

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `filter` using `filterMap`.
declarations.title: filterDefault

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `filter` using `partition`.
declarations.title: filterDefaultPartition

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `filter` using `partitionMap`.
declarations.title: filterDefaultPartitionMap

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `filterMap` using `separate`. Note that this is
almost certainly going to be suboptimal compared to direct implementations.
declarations.title: filterMapDefault

declarations.comments: Filter out all values.
declarations.title: cleared

declarations.comments:
`Filterable` represents data structures which can be _partitioned_/_filtered_.

- `partitionMap` - partition a data structure based on an either predicate.
- `partition` - partition a data structure based on boolean predicate.
- `filterMap` - map over a data structure and filter based on a maybe.
- `filter` - filter a data structure based on a boolean.

Laws:
- Functor Relation: `filterMap identity ≡ compact`
- Functor Identity: `filterMap Just ≡ identity`
- Kleisli Composition: `filterMap (l <=< r) ≡ filterMap l <<< filterMap r`

- `filter ≡ filterMap <<< maybeBool`
- `filterMap p ≡ filter (isJust <<< p)`

- Functor Relation: `partitionMap identity ≡ separate`
- Functor Identity 1: `_.right <<< partitionMap Right ≡ identity`
- Functor Identity 2: `_.left <<< partitionMap Left ≡ identity`

- `f <<< partition ≡ partitionMap <<< eitherBool` where `f = \{ no, yes } -> { left: no, right: yes }`
- `f <<< partitionMap p ≡ partition (isRight <<< p)` where `f = \{ left, right } -> { no: left, yes: right}`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `partitionDefault`
- `partitionDefaultFilter`
- `partitionDefaultFilterMap`
- `partitionMapDefault`
- `filterDefault`
- `filterDefaultPartition`
- `filterDefaultPartitionMap`
- `filterMapDefault`
declarations.title: Filterable

declarations.comments:
`Witherable` represents data structures which can be _partitioned_ with
effects in some `Applicative` functor.

- `wilt` - partition a structure with effects
- `wither` - filter a structure  with effects

Laws:

- Naturality: `t <<< wither f ≡ wither (t <<< f)`
- Identity: `wither (pure <<< Just) ≡ pure`
- Composition: `Compose <<< map (wither f) <<< wither g ≡ wither (Compose <<< map (wither f) <<< g)`
- Multipass partition: `wilt p ≡ map separate <<< traverse p`
- Multipass filter: `wither p ≡ map compact <<< traverse p`

Superclass equivalences:

- `partitionMap p = runIdentity <<< wilt (Identity <<< p)`
- `filterMap p = runIdentity <<< wither (Identity <<< p)`
- `traverse f ≡ wither (map Just <<< f)`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `wiltDefault`
- `witherDefault`
- `partitionMapByWilt`
- `filterMapByWither`
- `traverseByWither`
declarations.title: Witherable

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `partitionMap` given a `Witherable`.
declarations.title: partitionMapByWilt

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `filterMap` given a `Witherable`.
declarations.title: filterMapByWither

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `traverse` given a `Witherable`.
declarations.title: traverseByWither

declarations.comments: Partition between `Left` and `Right` values - with effects in `m`.
declarations.title: wilted

declarations.comments: Filter out all the `Nothing` values - with effects in `m`.
declarations.title: withered

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `wither` using `compact`.
declarations.title: witherDefault

declarations.comments: A default implementation of `wilt` using `separate`
declarations.title: wiltDefault
